header.title: Picatrix: Ghayat Al-Hakim (The Goal of the Wise)

central_thesis: The Picatrix aims to synthesize and reveal the concealed philosophical, astrological, and magical knowledge from ancient sages, offering a practical system for creating talismans by aligning human will with celestial influences through precise understanding and manipulation of planetary forces and their earthly correspondences, ultimately enabling the practitioner to achieve desired outcomes in the world of formation and dissolution.

structure_content.chapter_title: 0. Prologue
structure_content.summary: The author outlines his motivation for writing this book, 'The Goal of the Wise,' as a continuation of 'The Rank of the Wise,' to reveal concealed philosophical knowledge regarding magic and talismans, which he divides into four books, each with several chapters, starting in the year 343 and completed in 348.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter 1: The Virtue of Wisdom
structure_content.summary: This chapter defines wisdom as the knowledge of ultimate reasons for existence, tracing all beings back to the One Being. It categorizes wisdom into religious, natural, theological, and logical arts, emphasizing its necessity for comprehending the 'divine conclusion' (magical outcome) and achieving spiritual enlightenment and understanding of cause-and-effect in the world.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter 2: The Essence of Magic
structure_content.summary: Magic is defined as that which fascinates minds and attracts souls through words and deeds, stemming from a 'divine force'. A talisman is conceptualized as a 'spirit within a body,' operating via numerical ratios, astrological secrets, precise timing, and incenses to achieve 'domination and coercion.' The chapter differentiates between theoretical and practical magic, linking the latter to 'nayranjat' (magical tricks) and 'Alchemy'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter 3: The Essence and Reality of Astrology
structure_content.summary: Astrology is presented as an essential science for understanding the celestial sphere's perfect, circular nature and how planets influence Earth. It explains planetary effects on heat, humidity, and dryness, and introduces the concept of 'vagueness' as a philosophical method for concealing deeper meanings from the uninitiated.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter 4: The Use of Astrological Ratios in Making Talismans
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides specific instructions for talisman creation based on the Moon's position within its 28 lunar houses (e.g., Al-Sharatajn, Al-Botein, Al-Thurayya). It details the precise degrees and corresponding magical effects for diverse purposes, from causing discord and sabotaging relationships to promoting welfare, increasing crops, and attracting scorpions, stressing the importance of lunar phases and avoiding misfortunes for positive results.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter 5: Examples of Required Astrology Ratios to Make Talismans for Certain Functions
structure_content.summary: Practical examples for talisman construction are given, including uniting lovers, destroying enemies, improving cities, gaining wealth and status, influencing rulers, aiding slaves, preventing marriages, releasing captives, and fostering friendship. It introduces the significance of triangular, hexagonal, and quadrilateral astrological aspects in determining the nature of these magical operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter 6: The Importance of Mankind is Comparable to That of the Universe
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the concept of humanity as a 'microcosm' of the macrocosm, endowed with speech, animal, and plant characteristics. It draws extensive correspondences between human anatomy, senses, and internal functions with celestial bodies, planetary movements, and astrological principles, asserting that man reflects the universe and is capable of interacting with its forces through wisdom and knowledge.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter 7: The Vague Meaning of Being Has Been Concealed by Philosophers
structure_content.summary: The hierarchy of existence is described, from the High Being to celestial orbits, elements, metals, plants, animals, and 'speaking ones' (humans). It explains the 'ranks of being' (principle, element, primordial, etc.) and distinguishes between 'personal' and 'whole' primordial matter. The chapter emphasizes that only virtuous and pure individuals can truly grasp these hidden philosophical truths essential for magical practice.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 1: How This Knowledge Can Be Obtained
structure_content.summary: The author discusses the pursuit of philosophical secrets, especially those related to talismans, drawing inspiration from Ptolemy. He stresses the necessity of comprehensive knowledge in mathematical, physical, and metaphysical arts to understand the interaction between the higher and lower worlds, citing a historical account of a scorpion bite talisman as proof of efficacy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 2: The Constellation Figures and the Function of Their Symbols in the Motion of Planets
structure_content.summary: This chapter delves into the hidden meanings of celestial images within constellations, describing them in two phases: imaginary figures derived from fixed stars and Indian symbolic illustrations. It details how planetary characteristics are embedded in these images (e.g., Aries as a fierce man, Taurus as a cultivating woman) and how these symbols are used to decipher and activate magical actions and effects.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 3: The Effect of the High Planets and the Bad Omen of the Sun and the Moon
structure_content.summary: This section explains how planetary actions, particularly those of the Sun (O) and Moon (D), affect terrestrial phenomena, often linked to temperature. It examines various ancient traditions' views on the Moon's phases and its relationship to the Sun, emphasizing that while the Sun creates, the Moon reveals effects. Crucially, it provides guidance on favorable and unfavorable planetary alignments for talismanic work, such as avoiding eclipses and specific planetary misfortunes ('nuhus').

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 4: The Motion of The Stars (Planets)
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the concept of 'incoming-and-outgoing' movements of celestial bodies and constellations, which are crucial for producing desired magical effects. It provides a historical method for calculating these movements, referencing King Augustus and Diocletianus, and emphasizes that these phases are characteristics of the constellations' band, not the straight path.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 5: Distribution of This Science Among Nations
structure_content.summary: Hermes' classification of magic into three types is presented: talismanic (Sabians/Nabateans), astrological (Greeks), and 'qalaftirijat' or inspiration-based (Indians/Sakasiks/Copts). The chapter highlights specific esoteric knowledge attributed to Indians, such as poisons, musical magic, and anti-aging practices, concluding that talismans, by incorporating natural principles, are more effective than mere choices due to their inherent connection to the 'nature of the whole'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 6: The Characteristics and Contributions of Planets and How They Adapt to Their Functions
structure_content.summary: This chapter elaborates on how natural actions can be intensified or specialized for magical purposes, drawing parallels with medicine (e.g., scammonia for jaundice). It explains that a talisman's effectiveness comes from combining multiple ingredients that collectively accept a new desired image. The core principle is 'similitude and avoid contrariness,' meaning that magical elements should resonate with the desired outcome and avoid opposing forces.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 7: The Position of Phrases in Talismans and the Direction of Inserting Them in Talismans
structure_content.summary: This chapter discusses the significance of 'similitude and difference' in talismanic work, highlighting the functional relationship between planetary actions and the chosen stone, time, and place. It details how 'quantity,' divided into 'connected' (line, plane, body, time, place) and 'separate' (statement, number), is essential. The 'azimuth' (straight line between planets and talisman, and talisman and effect) is crucial for complete planetary 'contribution'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 8: The Order of Natural Matters and Their Supplements
structure_content.summary: This section explores the ancient philosophical understanding of combining natural bodies and their fundamental elements: heat, coldness, moisture, and dryness. It details various compound classifications, likening them to human organs, seasons, and natural processes. The text asserts that heat originates from celestial motion, while coldness derives from the Earth's center, underscoring the necessity of studying these arts.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 9: Picture Examples of fixed Planet Configurations
structure_content.summary: Specific talismanic symbols and their applications are provided for various purposes, such as repelling mice, mosquitoes, and flies; promoting enmity; vacating locations; and attracting desired individuals. The instructions include selecting appropriate materials (e.g., red tin plate, Sulphur stone, animal tusks) and aligning the creation with precise astrological timings (e.g., Moon in specific phases or ascendants).

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 10: Planets' Stones and Picture Drawings
structure_content.summary: This chapter exhaustively lists stones associated with each planet (Saturn: iron, diamond, onyx; Jupiter: lead, sapphire; Mars: red brass, magnet; Sun: gold, ruby; Venus: red brass, pearl; Mercury: idramus, emerald; Moon: silver, marble). It describes the symbolic images for each planet, referencing Apollonius and al-Katib, and provides detailed instructions for carving these images on specific stones during auspicious planetary hours to achieve diverse magical effects, from physical healing to social influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 11: The Front View of Constellations and Their Functions
structure_content.summary: The chapter details the visual images and symbolic characteristics associated with the three phases of each zodiacal constellation. It explains how these images correspond to planetary influences and specific life aspects (e.g., Aries for aggression, Taurus for cultivation, Gemini for knowledge). The text instructs practitioners to align talisman creation with these images during the appropriate constellation phases and planetary hours to manifest corresponding effects.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book II, Chapter 12: Dragon Pictures, Their Functions and Influences on How to Reflect and Attract Celestial Powers as Depicted in the Indian School of Thought (with) Examples of their Magic Works
structure_content.summary: This chapter explains the Indian practice of 'durayjanat,' where each 10-degree segment of an ascendant is linked to a planet, dictating talismanic efficacy. It provides specific durayjanat applications for war, rulers, judges, reconciliation, animosity, impotence, weather control, promoting trade, and attracting animals. The chapter stresses that successful actions depend on 'truthful thinking and sound intention,' as low forces attract high forces through shared essence, and highlights purification rituals for practitioners.

key_concepts.definition: The knowledge of sublime reasons for which beings exist, ascending in order to the One Being (Allah); encompassing religious, natural, theological, and logical arts, seen as essential for understanding and enacting magic.

Everything that absolutely fascinates minds and attracts souls by means of words and deeds, difficult for the simpleton to perceive, considered a divine force associated with advanced reasons for understanding it.

A 'spirit within a body' designed to exert 'domination, control, and coercion' by utilizing numerical ratios, astrological secrets, appropriate timing, specific materials, and incenses to bring forth its spirit and achieve a desired effect.

The science of understanding the celestial sphere, including fixed planets, constellation figures, planetary movements, their light, astrological ratios, and their implications on all beings in the world of formation and dissolution.
A term for magical tricks or practical magical operations, considered the best type of practical magic by the author, specialized in by the ancient Greeks.

The philosophical concept that a human being is a complete entity, a 'microcosm' confined within the larger world, reflecting the universe's form and content, thereby allowing for interaction and influence with celestial powers.

Astrological configurations or planets associated with bad luck, diseases, torture, killing, destruction, and adverse outcomes. These are typically avoided when making talismans for positive purposes.
Astrological configurations or planets associated with good fortune, happiness, love, friendship, and positive outcomes. These are sought when making talismans for beneficial purposes.

A concept from the Indian school of thought, where each ascendant is divided into three equal parts of 10 degrees each, with each 'durayjan' related to a specific planet, used for determining precise timing for talismanic operations.

A fundamental principle of magic where effective talismanic work requires aligning the qualities and characteristics of the materials, timing, and intention with the desired outcome (similitude) while avoiding opposing or contradictory elements (contrariety).

practical_system.description: The Picatrix presents a complex astrological-magical system for creating talismans to influence the material world. It operates on the principle of correspondences between macrocosm (celestial sphere, planets, constellations) and microcosm (humanity, materials). The core mechanic involves imbuing physical objects (talismans) with spiritual power by aligning their creation with specific, astrologically auspicious moments. This alignment is believed to open a conduit for planetary forces to manifest desired effects, making the talisman a 'spirit within a body' capable of 'coercion and control' over nature and human affairs.
tools: Astrological Ephemerides/Tables (for calculating planetary positions, hours, ascendants, lunar mansions, aspects)
Specific Stones (e.g., onyx, lapis azure, quartz, emerald, malachite, crystal, garnet, bezoar)
Specific Metals (e.g., gold, silver, red brass, tin, lead, iron)
Animal Parts (e.g., dog tusk, pig tusk, snake skin)
Ritual Vessels (e.g., lead bowls, silver poles)
Philosophical and Astrological Treatises (for theoretical understanding and guidance)
rituals: **Astrological Timing:** Precise calculation of planetary hours, ascendants, lunar phases (28 houses), and zodiacal constellation phases (3 per sign). Critical importance is placed on avoiding 'nuhus' (bad luck) planets, eclipses, and unfavorable aspects, while seeking 'sa'ad' (good luck) influences.

**Material Selection:** Choosing specific stones, metals (e.g., onyx for Sun, silver for Moon, iron for Saturn), animal parts (e.g., dog tusk, pig tusk), and plants that correspond to the desired planetary force and magical objective.

**Symbolic Carving & Engraving:** Creating images and symbols on selected materials that visually represent the celestial configurations and planetary intelligences. The orientation and method of carving (e.g., head first for repelling vs. tail first) are significant.

**Incense & Sacrifices:** Utilizing specific incenses (e.g., kundur resin) and sometimes making sacrifices to 'bring out the spirit' of the talisman and attract spiritual powers, often associated with planetary perfuming.

**Verbalization & Supplication:** Employing specific 'words and deeds,' including powerful statements and prayers, to consciously direct the practitioner's intention and align it with the celestial influences, enhancing the talisman's efficacy.

**Ritual Placement & Consecration:** Burying talismans in specific locations relevant to their purpose (e.g., location of love, city center, busiest road, burning earth) or wearing them on the body, to anchor and activate their influence in the physical world.

**Personal Purification:** The practitioner must undergo rigorous self-preparation, including isolation, purity of mind and body, fasting, ritual cleansing (e.g., washing seven times a day), and meditation, to align their own spirit and intention with divine and celestial forces.

relevant_quotes.text: The author has compiled information derived from 224 books by 'ancient sages' with the intention of uniting all these diverse arts into a practical system.
I sought to make it known and explain to the people the darkened path which leads to this divine conclusion and to point out what philosophers have concealed concerning this magical outcome...
Magic is, in fact, everything that absolutely fascinates minds and attract souls by means of words and deeds. A talisman is a spirit within a body, while chemistry is a body within a body.
If words reflect the intention of the speaker, he will be able to move the intention of the listener and vice versa.
The noblest science of stars is the science of talismans.
If you can make a move similar to and in agreement with a celestial movement and with a choice of stars, you will achieve your desire and fulfill your wish.
The focal point is the observation of stars.
My purpose for revealing this science is to promote reflection by those concerned.

critical_analysis.relevance: Picatrix is a cornerstone text in Western Esotericism, highly relevant for understanding the historical development and practical application of Hermetic, astrological, and talismanic magic. It serves as a vital bridge between medieval Arabic esoteric traditions and later European occultism, influencing major figures like Ficino and Agrippa. Its detailed instructions on planetary correspondences, celestial images, and ritualistic timing provide a comprehensive operative manual that continues to inform and inspire modern magical practices and historical studies of grimoires.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book is explicitly intended for 'seekers of knowledge,' 'researchers,' and 'philosophers' who possess a deep intellectual capacity and existing knowledge of various scientific and philosophical disciplines (mathematics, physics, metaphysics, theology, logic). It is not for the 'simpleton' or the 'uninformed,' as many core secrets are intentionally veiled. The practitioner is expected to be virtuous, pure in mind and body, and dedicated to intense study and self-mastery.
